headline.main: Google to Get Fiat Chrysler Minivans for Self-Driving Tests

docs.abstract: Google announces it will install its self-driving car technology in fleet of 100 minivans made by Fiat Chrysler; vehicles will be used to further test technology; deal is most prominent example of technology company working with automaker in field that has so far been defined by competition between two sectors.

docs.abstract: Google says it will ban all advertisements for payday loans and related products on its website; contends they frequently result in unaffordable repayment terms and financial damage to consumers.

headline.main: Another Company With a Cause: Is Google Just Being a Good Citizen?

docs.abstract: The Upshot; Google's banning of ads for payday loans in effect makes it financial regulator of sorts, since move is certain to hurt payday lenders, of which roughly one-third are online; protests are likely to grow if powerful tech firms continue to use their sway to further their causes in society.

headline.main: Want to Buy a Self-Driving Car? Big-Rig Trucks May Come First

docs.abstract: Otto, start-up led by former Google engineers, is working to create self-driving big-rig trucks; says developing expensive self-driving technology for commercial trucking industry before automobiles makes sense financially and more acceptable to regulators; some experts express concern that autonomous trucks would impact American economy by killing jobs for commercial drivers and small towns and peripherals that cater to them.

headline.main: Do You Love Music? Silicon Valley Doesn’t

headline.main: Google Prevails as Jury Rebuffs Oracle in Code Copyright Case
headline.print_headline: Google Prevails in Android Code Case

docs.abstract: Jury sides with Google following long legal battle with Oracle over open-source Java software that is used to power most of world's smartphones; Oracle wanted $9 billion for Google's use of software code in Android, but Google said it made fair use of code and owed nothing; Oracle will appeal copyright case.

byline.original: By NICK WINGFIELD and QUENTIN HARDY

headline.main: Don’t Hand Our TVs Over to Google
headline.print_headline: Save Our TVs From Google

docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by antitrust lawyer Jonathan Kanter warns Google may take unfair advantage of Federal Communications Commission decision requiring cable companies to hand over television programming data; points to Google's history of rigging search results in its own favor, harming other content providers and infringing on privacy; says if FCC provides Google with data needed to build its search-based set-top, it must at least ensure that Google commits to search neutrality.

headline.main: Rise of Ad-Blocking Software Threatens Online Revenue
headline.print_headline: Rise of Ad-Blocking Software Could Cost Web Companies Billions in Lost Revenue

docs.abstract: One in five smartphone users, amounting to almost 420 million people worldwide, use ad-blocking software when browsing web on their phones; shift threatens Internet companies like Google and Facebook that rely heavily on advertising.
